The US government utilized propaganda in creating an anti-communist narrative during the Vietnam War through a variety of means, including media and public relations campaigns. One of the primary tactics used was to portray the communist forces in Vietnam as a threat to American values and way of life.

The government used images and stories of the communist forces perpetrating acts of violence and atrocities against innocent civilians in Vietnam to stir up fear and outrage among the American public. The government also used fear-mongering language and exaggerated claims about the military strength of the communist forces in order to bolster support for the war effort and convince people of the need for continued American involvement.

In addition, the government used propaganda to discredit anti-war activists and those who opposed the war. They portrayed those who spoke out against the war as unpatriotic, disloyal, and sympathetic to the communist cause. This strategy was designed to silence dissenting voices and maintain a unified public image in support of the war effort.

Overall, the US government's propaganda efforts during the Vietnam War were designed to create a narrative that demonized communist forces and portrayed the war as necessary to protect American values and interests.

However, there were also instances in which the US government acknowledged and expressed regret for civilian deaths and damage to civilian infrastructure.

Despite this acknowledgement, the overall narrative of the war was heavily focused on blaming the communist forces for the suffering of civilians and the destruction of Vietnamese cities and villages. This narrative was intended to reinforce the US government's anti-communist stance and justify the continued American involvement in the war.

It is worth noting that the extent to which the US government acknowledged civilian casualties and destruction varied over time and depended on the political climate of the moment.
